text.body:
______
Chap. 8
one of my first duties on my recovery was
to introduce Clerval to the
^
several
professors of
the university. And in doing this I under
went torments a kind of rough usage
that ill befitten befitt ed ing
the wounds that
my mind had sustained. Ever since the
fatal night – the end of my labours &
the beginning of my misfortunes (
I had
conceived a violent antipathy even to
the name of
Ch Chemistry
Natural Philosophy
. When I was other
wise quite restored to health the sight of a
Chemical instrument brought on
again renewed
all
^
the agony of my
my
^ nervous symtoms. Lo
Henry saw this and had
p packed up removed
all my
machines in a chest
apparatus from my
che view
he had also
changed my
room ap p artment,
for he perceived that
I had
a
acquired
dislike to the room which had
previously been my workshop. But these
cares of Clerval were
thrown away
made of no avail
when
I visited the professors. even my excellent
M. Waldman inflicted torture when
he praised with the kindness and warmth,
the astonishing progress that I had made
in the sciences. He soon perceived
my
that I
dislike d of the subject, but not guessing
the real cause he attributed
to it
my feelings
to modesty on hearing myself praised
he therefore
and changed the subject from
my improvement, to the science itself,
with an a desire as I evidently saw
of drawing friend me out.
K Kind
friend he tortured me without but
it How cruel is What could I do?
He meant to please and me & he
tortured
tormented
me
it was
I felt as if he had
placed
carefully one by one placed in my
view those instruments which were
to be afterwards used in putting me to a
slow and cruel dre death. I writhed
under his words, yet dared not shew
my the pain I felt. Clerval, whose
eyes and feelings were always quick
in di s cerning the sensations of others
declined the subject alledging
in
^
his
ignorance & the conversation took
a more general turn. I thanked him
from my heart, but I did not speak.
I plainly saw that he was surprised,
but he never attempted to draw
my secret from me, and although
I loved him with a mixture of
love
affection
and reverence that knew no
bounds, yet I could never
pr persuade
myself to confide to him that event
which was so often present to my
thoughts, but which I feared the detail
to another would only impress more deeply.
M r . Krempe was not
^
equally
docile yet & weak
as my illness had made me
in my then
condition of
almost in
supportable
sensitiveness
his harsh
blunt econiums gave me even more
pain that than the benevolent
approbation of M. Waldman —"Dam m n
"the fellow," cried he "Why M r . Clerval
"I tell you he has beaut outstript
"us all– ay stare if you please but
"it is nevertheless true – A youngster
"who but two three years ago believed
"Cornelius Agrippa
to be
^
as firmly as the
gospel has
"now set himself at the head of
"the university & if he is not soon
"pulled down we shall all be out
"of countenance.—Aye, Aye, continued
"he observing my
countenance
^
face
ex
pressive of suffering "Mr. f
Franken
stein is modest an excellent quality in
"a young man; Young men should be
"diffident of themselves you know M
" Clerval; I was myself when young but
"one soon grows out of that."
M Krempe had now commenced
the subject of his own praise
an eulogy on himself
and that
happily turned the conversation
from the subject that was so
painful
agonizing
to me.
Clerval was no natural philosopher.
His imagination was too vivid for
the minutiæ of science.
La Lan
guages were his
chief
^
principal study for he
wished to open a field for
^
him
self-instruc
tion on his return – Greek Persian
& Arabic & Hebrew gained his atten
tion
when
X
so soon as X
he had become
perfect
ly master of the Greek & Latin langua
ges. For my own part idleness had
ever been irksome to me and
now that I wished to fly from reflec
tion and hated my former studies
a
I found great relief in being the
fellow pupil
of
with my fr friend and
I not a only found
instruct not only
instruc
tion but consolation in the works of
the orientalists.
There is something soothing
Their melancholy is soothing and their
joy elevating to a degree I never before
experienced in
reading
^
studying
any
^
the authors of
any
other
books.
^
country.
When you read
s their
li writings life
appears to consist in a warm sun
and gardens of roses – in the smiles &
tears
frowns
of a fair enemy and the fire
that consumes your own heart
How different from the man
^
l y & warlike
heroical
poet
ry
of Greece & Rome.
Summer passed away in these
studies
occupations
& my return to Geneva was
fixed for the latter end of Autum m n
but
being delayed by several accidents winter
& snow arrived, and the roads were
deemed impassable and my
return
^
journey
delayed
was
retarted
untill the
^
ensuing
spring. I felt this
delay very bitterly
^
for I longed to see my
native
c t own and my beloved friends
and my return had only been delayed
so long from an unwillingness to leave
Clerval in a strange town before he
had become acquainted with its in
habitants. The winter
^
however
was
however
s spent
a cheerful ly one and although the
spring was uncommonly late when
it came its beauty compensated
for its dilatoriness. Ma The month
of May was already finis end com
pleated, and I expected daily the
letter that was to fix the date of
my
return
^
departure,
When Henry proposed
a pedestrian tour in environs of
Ingolstadt that I might bid farewell
to the country I had so long in
habited.– I acceeded with pleasure to
this propos al
^
ition – I was fond of Exercise
and Clerval had always been my
favourite companion in
j
^
the
rambles
of this nature that I had taken
among the scenes of my native coun
try. We passed a fortnight in these
perambulations. My health and spirits had long
been restored and they gained add i it ional vigour
from the salubrious air , X
I breathed,
X
the natural
incidents of
our progress X
and the
conversation of my friend. Study had before
rendered me unsocia ble l, –I had shunned the face
company of my fellow beings But Clerval
called forth the better feelings of my heart.
he again taught me to love the aspect
of nature and the cheerful faces of chil
dren. Excellent Friend! How sincerely did you
love me and endeavour to elevate my
mind untill it was on a level with
your own. A selfish persuit e had cramp
ed and narrowed
it
^
me untill your gentle
ness & affection warmed & opened
it
^
my senses
. and
now I
^
now
became the same happy creature
who a few years ago, loving & beloved by
all, had no sorrow or care – I and when
happy so
soul was more fitted than mine
for feeling delight in inanimate nature
X
X had the
power of
bes
bo towing on
me the most
delightful
sensations
—
A serene sky filled and verdant
s fields
filled me with extasy.– t T he
^
present season was indeed
divine – the flowers of spring
blossomed
^
bloomed
in the
hedges while those of summer were al
ready in bud– I dis was not disturbed by
thoughts that during the preceeding
year pressed upon me not withstand
ing my endeavours to throw them off with an invincible burthen.
Henry a rejoiced
im in my gaiety and
sincerely sympathized in my
joy feelings – he exer
ted himself to amuse me, while he expressed
the feelings that al filled his
mind
^
soul . The
resources of his mind on this occasion
were truly astonishing. As we rested during
the sultry heat of noon he invented
his conversation was full of imagination
and very often, in imitation of the persi
an& Arabic writers, he invented tales
of
great
^
wonderful
fancy and interrest. At other
times he repeated my favourite poems
or drew me out into arguments which
he supported with great ingenuity.
We returned
^
to our colledge
on a sunday – the pea
sants were dancing and every one we
met appeared joyful and happy – my
own spirits were high and I bounded
along with a feelings of
hilarity unbound
ed
unbridled
joy and hilarity.
20
15
